--- title: Managing events and APIs from a unified environment 300-level live demo description: Managing events and APIs from a unified environment tabs: [ 'Demo preparation', 'Demo script'] --- export const Title = () => (

Managing events and APIs from a unified environment
300-level live demo

 ); ![banner](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibm-garage-tsa/platinum-demos/master/src/pages/300-integration-managing-events-and-apis-from-unified-environment/images/managing-events-apis-preparation-banner-10-27-22.jpg) | DEMO OVERVIEW | | | --------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | | **Scenario overview** | This demo compares exposing data from an airport’s flight information system over REST APIs and over an event stream. A Flight Information Board will get flight information using a traditional REST API. We will then show how a new event stream for flight information on can be easily made available to the developers of an airline mobile application. This will enable the mobile app to receive flight delays the moment they occur, resulting in an improved and more marketable experience. | | **Demo products** | Cloud Pak for Integration | | **Demo capabilities** | API and event management; Event streams | | **Demo intro slides** | Download the Introduction and Overview slides here. This is a short deck of customer-facing slides that sets the context for the demo. | | **Demo script** | A complete demo script is on the second tab above. You can download a printer-ready PDF of the demo script here.

This demo script has multiple tasks that each have multiple steps. In each step, you have the details about what you need to do (**Actions**), what you can say while delivering this demo step (**Narration**), and what diagrams and screenshots you will see.

This demo script is a suggestion, and you are welcome to customize based in your sales opportunity. Most importantly, practice this demo in advance. If the demo seems easy for you to execute, the customer will focus on the content. If it seems difficult for you to execute, the customer will focus on your delivery. | | **Sales enablement video** | View the enablement video here. This video is for enablement purposes only (IBMers and Business Partners) and is not customer-ready. | | **Required versions** | Cloud Pak for Integration V2022.2 | | **How to get support** | **For IBMers:**
• Contact #itz-techzone-support or techzone.help@ibm.com regarding issues with reserving and provisioning Tech Zone environments.
• Contact #platinumdemos-automation-support regarding issues with setting up and running this demo.

**For Business Partners:**
• Contact Tech Zone Support regarding issues with reserving and provisioning Tech Zone environments.
• Contact Automation Platinum Demos Support regarding issues with setting up and running this demo. | ### **DEMO INSTALLATION AND SETUP**
1 - Provision Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud for Cloud Pak for Integration
Install Cloud Pak for Integration, or provision a ROKS environment. To reserve your ROKS instance, follow these steps: Provision Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud (ROKS) ready to install the Cloud Pak for Integration. To provision your ROKS instance, follow these steps:

TechZone has terminated the Practice / Self-Education purpose to obtain the ROKS environment needed to practice and give this demo. You must now choose a purpose that requires a sales opportunity number (customer demo, PoC, PoT) to gain access to a ROKS environment. A non-ROKS environment for practice and self-education is coming in the second quarter.

If you are taking the Cloud Pak for Integration for Technical Sales Level 3 Course, use this link to reserve a ROKS environment for badge completion purposes.
1. To reserve a preinstalled Cloud Pak for Integration (CP4I) ROKS cluster on Red Hat OpenShift, go here and complete the form.
2. You will receive a confirmation email confirming the instance is provisioning.
3. You will receive a second email once the environment is provisioned. You should expect this to take between 30 and 120 minutes. This email contains information, such as URLs, allowing you to connect to the instance.

If you have issues connecting to your instance, please contact #itz-techzone-support.
**[Go to top](#top)**
2 - Install Cloud Pak for Integration on a ROKS cluster
1. Click the **Cluster URL** from the environment confirmation email. Log into IBM Cloud using your IBMid.


2. After you are logged in, click here to install Cloud Pak for Integration.

Make sure you are in an **ITZ** account (1) and the **Product version** is **2022.2.1** (2).


3. Scroll down to the **Select your cluster** section. From the list, select the **Red Hat OpenShift Cluster** (1) that you just created and click **Add project** (2).


4. Enter **'cp4i'** (1) as the **Project** name. Click **Add** (2).


5. Scroll down to the **Set the deployment values** section and toggle the **Use an existing secret?** slider to **No** (1). Enter a value for **csDefaultAdminPassword** (2). You must choose a password that is 32 characters in length and composed of only letters and numbers. You will need this password in step 12.

Password validation is currently not enforced on this page. If you proceed with an invalid password, you can to start the installation, but it will fail. There is no way to recover from this error other than provisioning a new cluster.

6. Scroll down to **Optional deployment values** and click the collapsible section to open them. Configure the one-click install for this demo by setting the **cognitiveCarRepair** field to **true**. Leave all other fields **false**.


7. Continue to change the default values parameters using the table below.

If you don’t have an SMTP email server and accounts that you can use, you may sign up for a free Mailtrap.io account. Mailtrap.io is a free cloud service that mimics an SMTP server. It is used for development/demonstration purposes only.
| FIELD | ACTION | | ------ | ------- | | **demoAPICMailServerHost:** (1)| If you’re using mailtrap, leave this smtp.mailtrap.io. | | **demoAPICMailServerPort:** (2)| If you’re using mailtrap, leave this as 2525. | | **demoAPICEmailAddress:** (3)| If you’re using mailtrap, you can use any email address.
The dummy address ’apicadmin@example.com’ is recommended. If you’re using your own mail server, use an email address that you can receive and read. | | **demoAPICMialServerUsername:** (4)| Set this to your SMTP mailtrap username. This is different from your mailtrap login username and can be found by using these instructions. | | **demoAPICMailServerPassword:** (5)| Set this to your SMTP mailtrap password. This is different from your mailtrap login password and can be found by using these instructions. |


8. Accept the license agreement (1) and click **Install** (2) to install Cloud Pak for Integration. The installation can take up to 150 minutes.


9. You can view the progress in the schematics progress bar that automatically displays.


If your install fails, you must go to your My reservations page, delete your environment, and start again from step 1 - Provision a Cloud Pak for Integration environment.
10. When the status updates to **Active** (1), you can access Cloud Pak for Integration Platform Navigator. Click **Offering Dashboard** (2) on the upper right corner of the page.


11. On the login page, select the authentication type **IBM provided credentials (admin only)**.


12. Use the admin username and **Password** (1) you created in step 5 and click **Log in** (2).


13. Click **Integration instances**.


You have successfully completed cluster provisioning, installation of Cloud Pak for Integration, and API Connect and App Connect deployment. You are ready to proceed.
**[Go to top](#top)**
3 - Access your ROKS cluster and install the command line
In this section, you access your ROKS cluster and install the OpenShift command line tool. If you already have the command line tool, you can proceed to **Access your ROKS cluster using CLI**.
1. Open My reservations in **IBM Technology Zone**.
2. Select you **CP4I ROKS** cluster.


3. Click **Open your Managed OpenShift (ROKS) environment**.


4. Click **OpenShift web console**.


5. On the web console page, click **?** (1), and select **Command line tools** (2).


6. Follow the links to install the OpenShift Command Line Interface (CLI) for your Operating System.


7. Log into your OpenShift cluster using CLI. From the dropdown menu in the upper right of the page, under your **username** (1), click **Copy login command** (2).


8. Click **Display Token**.


9. Copy the **login** command.


10. Open your terminal window and paste the **login command** to access your OpenShift cluster.


**[Go to top](#top)**
4 - Clone the demo assets from a GitHub repository
To copy the repo you will need to have the Git CLI on your machine. If you don’t have it, follow the installation steps described on this page, based on your operating system.
1. To download the scripts to run the demo, create a directory, and from there run the following command:
``` git clone https://github.com/IBM/platinum-demo-code-eem.git ```

2. This will download several folders. The demo material is in the folder ‘demo-script’. Change directories by running:
``` cd platinum-demo-code-eem/scripts/ ```

In this directory you will see the following two files that you need to set up the demo:
**setup-software.sh** - Sets up EEM and Event Streams
**setup-app.sh** - Sets up the Flight Board application
**[Go to top](#top)**
5 - Install and configure Event Streams and Event Endpoint Management
1. Run the following command:
``` ./setup-software.sh cp4i ``` This could take 10-20 minutes to complete. It will be complete when Event Endpoint Management and IBM Event Streams has been installed.

The Platform Navigator and Event Streams UI endpoints are displayed at the end of the script for convenience. These will be used later.
2. Navigate to the Event Stream UI outputted in the previous step.

3. Log in with the username **admin** and the password you created in step 2.5. This opens **IBM Event Steams**.


4. Select the **topics** (1) icon, then click **Create topic** (2).


5. Specify **flight-delays** (1) as the **Topic name** and select **Next** (2).


6. Click **Next**.


7. Click **Next**.


8. Click **Create topic**.


9. Next, open a browser window and go to the **Platform Navigator URL** from step 5.1.


10. Expand the menu in the top left (1) and select **Integration instances** under **Administration**.


11. Select **ademo** corresponding to the **API management administration** type.


12. Select the **Topology** icon (1), and click **Register service** (2).


13. Select **Event Gateway Service**.


14. For the configuration of the Event Gateway Service, two endpoints are needed. To retrieve these, run Run the following command:
``` ./get-urls.sh cp4i ```


15. Configure with the following details:

**Title**: event-gateway-service (1)
**Management endpoint**: the value outputted from the above (note that this **should** begin with https://) (2)
**API endpoint base**: the value outputted from above (note that this should **NOT** begin with https://) (3)

Click **Save** (4).


16. The Event Gateway Service needs to be associated with the API Connect Catalog. Navigate to API Management by selecting the menu at the top left and selecting **APIs** under the **Design** section.


17. Select **Manage** (1) and click on the **Sandbox** (2) catalog.


18. Select the **Catalog settings** (1) tab, then the **Gateway services** section (2) and click **Edit** (3).


19. Check the box associated with the **event-gateway-service** (1) and click **Save (2)**.


20. Set up the client certificates.
21. Next, create the Dev User for the Developer Portal. Click on the **Home** icon (1), and **Manage catalogs** (2).


22. Open **Sandbox**.


23. Open **Catalog settings** (1), then **Portal** (2).


24. Since a developer portal does not already exist, click **Create**.


25. Select **portal-service** (1) from the pull down. Click **Create** (2).


26. The portal will take around 5 minutes to be built, but the URL is immediately displayed. Copy the URL, open a new browser tab, and paste your **Portal URL**. It may take several minutes and browser refreshes to appear.


27. On the Portal page, click **Create account**.


28. Complete the form.
As a suggestion, use devuser as the Username. Any working email address will work for Email address.

29. To complete your registration, you need to open your email and accept the registration.
If you are using mailtrap, you need to open your mailtrap inbox and accept the registration.

Congratulations! Your portal developer user has been created and you are ready for the demo.
**[Go to top](#top)**
6 - Install the Flight Board app
1. Run the following commands:
``` cd platinum-demo-code-eem/scripts/ ``` ``` ./setup-app.sh cp4i ``` It takes a few minutes to configure access and generate credentials for the flight board app.
2. Open a browser window for each of the URLs that are created: one is for the **FlightBoard** app and the other is for ** FlightBoard Manager**.


Note that the links use http not https. If you see a page saying that the application is not available, then you have likely got https in the URL.
**[Go to top](#top)**
7 - Import and deploy the Flight API
The Flight API will be exposed through API Connect. This allows controlled, secure exposure to the API.
1. Select the **draft** icon (1). Click **Add** and select **API** (2).


2. Scroll down and select **Existing OpenAPI** (1) and click **Next** (2).


3. Click here to get a text file required for the demo.


4. Using your browser, save the page as a Text file (1), naming it **FlightAPI.yaml** (2).


5. Upload the **FlightAPI.yaml** file in API Manager and click **Next** (2).


6. Click **Next**.


7. Check the **Activate API** (1) option. Click **Next** (2).


8. Click **Develop**.


**[Go to top](#top)**
## **PREPARE TO GIVE THE DEMO**
Open these resources before starting demonstration
1. Download the **Flight-Delay.avsc** schema from here. You will need this for Action 4.1.5 of the demonstration.

2. Open the following tabs in a web browser:
• IBM Event Streams
• IBM Cloud Pak for Integration Platform Navigator
• The Flight Board
• The Flight Board Manager
• IBM API Connect Developer Portal

These URLs are provided as the output from the setup-software.sh and setup-app.sh scripts. For convenience you can also get the URLs for the above by running the following command from the eem-demo/scripts folder:
``` $ ./get-urls.sh ```
3. Click **Sign in** to log in to the Developer Portal using the devuser account you created in the preparation steps above.


4. Enter the **Username** and **Password**. Click **Sign in**.


5. Prepare a terminal by logging into the OpenShift cluster with the “Copy login command” option from the OpenShift user interface, then executing it within the terminal window.



**[Go to top](#top)**
Click [here](/300-integration-managing-events-and-apis-from-unified-environment/demo-script) to go to the **Demo script** on the next tab.
